bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Eugene "Rocky" Staples was a foundation program officer and executive, journalist, diplomat, and World War II veteran. He held numerous positions at the Ford Foundation between 1964 and 1981, primarily concerned with the Foundation's Asia programming. In 1992, he helped found the Eurasia Foundation, and he served as President of that organization until his retirement in 1997.

Staples joined the Ford Foundation in 1964 as Associate Director of Policy and Planning. In 1966, he started his work with the Foundation's Asia programs as Deputy Director of South and Southeast Asia. He occupied a number of different positions in the succeeding years. Some of his position title changes reflect the Foundation's reorganization and retitling of its programming for Asia. For example, he was Head of South and Southeast Asia and then Head of Asia and Pacific. In 1973, he became the Foundation's Representative for Southeast Asia, and in 1976, he became the Foundation's Representative for India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. He stayed in that last position until he left the Foundation in 1981. The Foundation later commissioned Staples to write a brief history about the Foundation's history of programming in India. Staples' volume, "Forty Years: A Learning Curve, The Ford Foundation in India, 1952-1992" was published in 1992.

Prior to joining the Ford Foundation, Staples had a career in journalism and diplomacy as a United Press correspondent in Mexico, a United States Foreign Service press officer in Uruguay and Chile, and Cultural Counselor at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow, Russia. He also served as a U.S. Marine Corps fighter pilot in World War II.

After leaving the Ford Foundation, Staples joined the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) in 1981. He served in Pakistan from 1985 until he left the organization in 1988. Then, from 1992 to 1997, he served as President of the Eurasia Foundation which he helped establish.

Staples' education focused on foreign language learning. Fluent in Spanish and Russian, he graduated from the English-language Mexico City College and did advanced Russian language studies through the State Department and U.S. Army. Staples died in 2013.
